{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3297792,"name":"ERIC ZACHERL","username":"ejzacherl","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-30T14:22:34.577Z","cooked":"

For those of you having trouble with SysID and the auto generated CTRE swerve code. Here are lessons learned from our struggles.

  1. @jasondaming wrote some excellent code for this purpose. Thank you Jason! We used it and found it helpful. Be careful to grab the pertinent code from all of the java classes if you are copying and pasting into your own.

  2. You must grab the .hoot file log from your robot using Tuner X. Then convert it to .wpilog using the Tuner X convert tool.

  3. Be careful which .hoot log file you grab. We installed a USB drive into our RoboRio 1. Leave the USB drive in the rio and remotely pull the data from it. Otherwise, you risk corrupting the data by pulling the drive while it is being written.

  4. We mistakenly kept pulling from the logs directory on the rio itself instead of from the USB drive. The .hoot file in the rio logs directory has some state text in it, but no numerical data. This was a great source of frustration for us. You can tell if you have the right .hoot file if it is in the range of 100MB large. To find the log from the USB drive you need to navigate through the directory structure. I think ours was under “/mnt/sda1”, but I could be mistaken.

  5. When running the characterization tests, the quasistatic test can’t be run twice without a code restart. The subsequent time you run it, the speed will start where you left off from the previous quasistatic test.

Hope this helps!

ejzacherl:

When running the characterization tests, the quasistatic test can’t be run twice without a code restart. The subsequent time you run it, the speed will start where you left off from the previous quasistatic test.

Courtesy of @ArchdukeTim, this will be fixed in the next WPILib release.

I would hardly say that most of this is “my” code. I got much of it from @daltzsmith and other CTRE employees in testing the SysID stuff.

Much of this same code will be integrated into a CTRE example “soon”.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-01-30T16:00:57.659Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":599,"readers_count":598,"score":224.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"Jason Daming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/jasondaming/ctre_swerve","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - jasondaming/ctre_swerve: Swerve drive using the CTRE with PP example and Swerve Builder.","clicks":351}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18342,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/4","custom_user_title":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3297941,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-30T17:03:22.975Z","cooked":"
ejzacherl:

We mistakenly kept pulling from the logs directory on the rio itself instead of from the USB drive. The .hoot file in the rio logs directory has some state text in it, but no numerical data.

The Phoenix 6 signal logger does not log to both locations at the same time. We log to the first USB drive found at /u/logs, and if there is no USB drive found we switch to logging at /home/lvuser/logs. This is documented in the SignalLogger.setPath() API docs. The logs you’re seeing on the roboRIO are probably older logs; double check the logs’ timestamps.

ejzacherl:

Otherwise, you risk corrupting the data by pulling the drive while it is being written.

Just a note on this, in many circumstances the data corruption results in losing the last few seconds of data, but the rest of the file is often still okay. In general though, we recommend stopping the signal logger before pulling the hoot file off the roboRIO.

ejzacherl:

You can tell if you have the right .hoot file if it is in the range of 100MB large.

I’d expect the exported WPILOG to be that large, not the hoot file. A 2-minute hoot file of a swerve drivebase should be around 10-15 MB.

ejzacherl:

To find the log from the USB drive you need to navigate through the directory structure. I think ours was under “/mnt/sda1”, but I could be mistaken.

I haven’t tested it, but you might be able to navigate to /u/logs in the Tuner X download panel to access the USB drive. You can type in the directory at the top of the panel and press Enter to navigate.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-01-30T17:06:26.602Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":572,"readers_count":571,"score":294.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/java/com/ctre/phoenix6/SignalLogger.html#setPath(java.lang.String)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SignalLogger (CTRE Phoenix 6 Java 24.1.0)","clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/5","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3298016,"name":"ERIC ZACHERL","username":"ejzacherl","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-30T18:29:48.490Z","cooked":"

Thanks for your thoughtful response.

bhall-ctre:

The Phoenix 6 signal logger does not log to both locations at the same time. We log to the first USB drive found at /u/logs, and if there is no USB drive found we switch to logging at /home/lvuser/logs. This is documented in the SignalLogger.setPath() API docs. The logs you’re seeing on the roboRIO are probably older logs; double check the logs’ timestamps.

We definitely had multiple .hoot files with similar if not the same timestamps on them. Could this be caused by calling the Logger start method in more than one place? We have it in RobotInit and in the auto generated Telemetry class.

bhall-ctre:

I’d expect the exported WPILOG to be that large, not the hoot file. A 2-minute hoot file of a swerve drivebase should be around 10-15 MB.

I probably was looking at the .wpilog file size instead of .hoot. Sorry for any confusion.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-01-30T18:29:48.490Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":473,"readers_count":472,"score":194.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"ERIC ZACHERL","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5740"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5740","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3298017,"name":"ERIC ZACHERL","username":"ejzacherl","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-30T18:32:24.672Z","cooked":"

Thanks so much. You contributed to our success!

jdaming:

The link to the repo.

I would hardly say that most of this is “my” code. I got much of it from @daltzsmith and other CTRE employees in testing the SysID stuff.

Much of this same code will be integrated into a CTRE example “soon”.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-01-30T18:33:05.115Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":461,"readers_count":460,"score":202.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"ERIC ZACHERL","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5740"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5740","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299465,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T14:54:13.080Z","cooked":"

IS there a mechanism for characterizing for the FOC control requests? The feed forward in FOC is in Amps.

The Sysid framework seems tied to Volts not Amps.

I assume the kS, kV, and kA fed into a SimpleMotorFeedForward would work if those units were Amps and it would just produce Amps.

Some CTR documentation refers to kT, is that just one of the above constants in Amps as the unit?

@Oblarg @bhall-ctre

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-02-01T14:54:13.080Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":481,"readers_count":480,"score":186.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"Brad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38557,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector "},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/8","custom_user_title":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299495,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T15:40:42.608Z","cooked":"

You can pipe the voltage signal to TorqueCurrentFOC mode and run analysis pretending that current is voltage, and it’ll work.

You have to be careful not to hit 100% duty cycle during your test routines, and the behavior/diagnostics will look rather different:

image1920×1163 233 KB

Velocity over time should be quadratic for the ramp test and linear for the step test. If there’s substantial viscous friction, the step test might show some exponential decay as well, and kV will be nonzero.

The 2025 SysIdRouinte API will probably have to introduce a minor breaking change to represent this properly, and return the control signal as a double instead of a voltage. Too late to change this for this season. The analyzer might get an update to handle this a bit more gracefully this season, though i make no promises.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-02-01T15:43:48.176Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":67,"reads":473,"readers_count":472,"score":574.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/a/d/ad00a5a5f5fdb710823d2474827867492f210ffa.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/using-sysid-with-torquefoc/454175/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Using SysId with TorqueFOC","clicks":25},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/characterizing-torque-based-foc-velocity-with-sysid/459287/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Characterizing Torque Based (FOC) velocity with sysID","clicks":14},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/foc-sysid-issue/491990/4","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"FOC + SysID issue","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38557,"username":"Bmongar","name":"Brad","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/9","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299499,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T15:45:21.879Z","cooked":"
Oblarg:

You can pipe the voltage signal to TorqueCurrentFOC mode and run analysis pretending that current is voltage, and it’ll work.

That is what I was hoping to hear.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-02-01T15:45:21.879Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":441,"readers_count":440,"score":123.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"Brad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38557,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector "},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/10","custom_user_title":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector ","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3300170,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-02T12:20:10.384Z","cooked":"
Oblarg:

You have to be careful not to hit 100% duty cycle during your test routines, and the behavior/diagnostics will look rather different:

By careful you mean the data will be bad or we will release the magic smoke?

Still awaiting bot for full test but here is what we have , was trying to guess at good ramp rates and stem amperage.

  // Mutable holder for unit-safe voltage values, persisted to avoid reallocation.
  private final MutableMeasure<Voltage> m_appliedVoltage = mutable(Volts.of(0));
  // Mutable holder for unit-safe rotational distance values, persisted to avoid
  // reallocation.
  private final MutableMeasure<Angle> m_rotation = mutable(Rotations.of(0));
  // Mutable holder for unit-safe rotational  velocity values, persisted to avoid
  // reallocation.
  private final MutableMeasure<Velocity<Angle>> m_velocity = mutable(RotationsPerSecond.of(0));
  private final TorqueCurrentFOC m_torqueCurrentFOC = new TorqueCurrentFOC(0);
  private final SysIdRoutine m_sysIdRoutine = new SysIdRoutine(
      // Using amperage, since it is converted when it comes out it ok.  Config expecst type volts.
      new SysIdRoutine.Config(Volts.of(5).per(Seconds.of(1)), Volts.of(30), null, null),
      new SysIdRoutine.Mechanism(
          // Tell SysId how to plumb the driving voltage to the motors.
          (Measure<Voltage> volts) -> {
            rightMotor.setControl(m_torqueCurrentFOC.withOutput(volts.in(Volts)));
          },
          // Tell SysId how to record a frame of data for each motor on the mechanism
          // being
          // characterized.
          log -> {
            // Record a frame for the wheel motor.
            log.motor("wheel")
                .voltage(
                    m_appliedVoltage.mut_replace(
                        rightMotor.get() * RobotController.getBatteryVoltage(), Volts))
                .angularPosition(m_rotation.mut_replace(rightMotor.getPosition().getValueAsDouble(), Rotations))
                .angularVelocity(
                    m_velocity.mut_replace(rightMotor.getVelocity().getValueAsDouble(), RadiansPerSecond));

          },
          // Tell SysId to make generated commands require this subsystem, suffix test
          // state in
          // WPILog with this subsystem's name ("LauncherRollers")
          this));

  public Command sysIdQuasistatic(SysIdRoutine.Direction direction) {
    return m_sysIdRoutine.quasistatic(direction);
  }

  public Command sysIdDynamic(SysIdRoutine.Direction direction) {
    return m_sysIdRoutine.dynamic(direction);
  }

Not sure how we messed up, we ran all the tests but our files don’t seem to have the sysid tests in them. IT isn’t swerve characterization but an arm.

The logs can be found here Sysid - Google Drive

Code is here GitHub - FRC-5013-Park-Hill-Robotics/2024-Crescendo

The mechanism we are trying to characterize is the Intake Wrist

github.com

FRC-5013-Park-Hill-Robotics/2024-Crescendo/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/sysID/IntakeWristId.java

// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.

package frc.sysID;

import com.ctre.phoenix6.controls.TorqueCurrentFOC;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.hardware.TalonFX;

import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Volts;
import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Radians;
import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.RadiansPerSecond;
import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Seconds;
import static edu.wpi.first.units.MutableMeasure.mutable;

import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.ArmFeedforward;
import edu.wpi.first.units.Angle;
import edu.wpi.first.units.Measure;
import edu.wpi.first.units.MutableMeasure;
import edu.wpi.first.units.Velocity;
This file has been truncated. show original

Now we are trying to use amps and let the system think it is volts for the purpose of analysis

    private final MutableMeasure<Voltage> m_appliedVoltage = mutable(Volts.of(0));
    // Mutable holder for unit-safe linear distance values, persisted to avoid
    // reallocation.
    private final MutableMeasure<Angle> m_rotation = mutable(Radians.of(0));
    // Mutable holder for unit-safe linear velocity values, persisted to avoid
    // reallocation.
    private final MutableMeasure<Velocity<Angle>> m_velocity = mutable(RadiansPerSecond.of(0));
     private final TorqueCurrentFOC m_torqueCurrentFOC = new TorqueCurrentFOC(0);
    private final SysIdRoutine m_sysIdRoutine = new SysIdRoutine(
            // Empty config defaults to 1 volt/second ramp rate and 7 volt step voltage.
            new SysIdRoutine.Config( Volts.of(10).per(Seconds.of(1)), Volts.of(65), null,null),
            new SysIdRoutine.Mechanism(
                    // Tell SysId how to plumb the driving voltage to the motors.
                    (Measure<Voltage> volts) -> {
                        intakeWristMotor.setControl(m_torqueCurrentFOC.withOutput(volts.in(Volts)));
                    },
                    // Tell SysId how to record a frame of data for each motor on the mechanism
                    // being
                    // characterized.
                    log -> {
                        // Record a frame for the wrist motor. 
                        log.motor("wrist")
                                .voltage(
                                        m_appliedVoltage.mut_replace(intakeWristMotor.getTorqueCurrent().getValueAsDouble()
                                                , Volts))
                                .angularPosition(m_rotation.mut_replace(offsetPosition(), Radians))
                                .angularVelocity(
                                        m_velocity.mut_replace(encoder.getVelocityRadians(), RadiansPerSecond));

                    },
                    // Tell SysId to make generated commands require this subsystem, suffix test
                    // state in
                    // WPILog with this subsystem's name ("IntakeWrist")
                    this));

    public Command sysIdQuasistatic(SysIdRoutine.Direction direction) {
        return m_sysIdRoutine.quasistatic(direction);
    }

    public Command sysIdDynamic(SysIdRoutine.Direction direction) {
        return m_sysIdRoutine.dynamic(direction);
    }

eddieD:

aren’t sure what is the intent of the RampRate, and StepVoltage are.

The quasistatic test uses RampRate as the excitation increase rate of your mechanism. The goal here is to set it so that you can get enough data points before you run out of room to run your mechanism. A slow rate “could” be better for your arm.

The Dynamic test uses StepVoltage to excite your mechanism. The goal here is to set the step size as large as possible without harming your mechanism or make belts slip, etc. A step response tells you a lot about the stability of your systems feedback loop(s).

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-02-14T14:48:20.597Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":324,"readers_count":323,"score":104.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"ERIC ZACHERL","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5740"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/16","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5740","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3309265,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-14T15:18:38.424Z","cooked":"

I have a few questions. Not challenging the discussion, just trying to hone my understanding.

Bmongar:

IS there a mechanism for characterizing for the FOC control requests? The feed forward in FOC is in Amps.

Is this completely accurate? I certainly could be wrong. I agree the units are amps when the control mode is TorqueCurrentFOC. However, if FOC is enabled and the control mode is duty cycle or voltage, aren’t the feedforward units still in duty cycle or voltage, respectively?

Bmongar:

Some CTR documentation refers to kT

Where did you see kT? I could be missing it, but I don’t see it in the documentation or in the API.


Bmongar:

IT isn’t swerve characterization but an arm.

Assuming your goal is position control on your arm, TorqueCurrentFOC might not be the best control choice. To quote some info I got from CTRE, “Voltage is generally appropriate for Position based control, as voltage is proportional to the velocity of the motor. Torque is useful for Velocity based control, as torque is proportional to acceleration.” Again, I’m no expert, just sharing my understanding.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":58,"updated_at":"2024-02-21T15:36:33.200Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":69.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":452631,"topic_slug":"sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44380,"username":"gdefender","name":"Andy Gasser","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/sysid-with-ctre-swerve-characterization/452631/19","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3314478,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-21T17:27:56.529Z","cooked":"

I’m also just getting started, but I had far more success running the SysID routines and manually analyzing the log with AdvantageScope, and then tuning with Tuner X. Well over 50% of the time SysID generates invalid results, with a negative kS value.

Tuner X is really useful. You can run the motor with all of the control modes (even motion magic, etc.), put data on the real-time graph, and tune the gains to see immediate results.

We don’t have any mechanisms with multiple motors this year, but I imagine that could be harder to tune with this approach.
